channel.title: Some things I want to ask
channel.description:
I haven't been connected with the RSC scene much in the past year (give or take a few months, I can't remember). How are things going as far as development? Any new dupes found? Fill me in.
I also wanted to ask if DDoS is still a problem for server owners. If so is it as bad as it was like a year+ ago (bigger attacks)?

item.title: Some things I want to ask
item.dc:creator: @nolan2131 nolan2131
item.description:
@nolan2131 wrote:

Not much is changing in my opinion.

Read full topic

item.description:
@mona_lisa wrote:

[quote=“IlikeArrays, post:45, topic:398710”][quote author=NoLives link=topic=495848.msg3633321#msg3633321 date=1308415465]

The DDoS problem of public servers is the reason why I will not even bother to spend time developing a server anymore. RIP RSC development.
[/quote]You speak the truth.
Fact is, Kryptix is probably the sole reason for rsc dying.

I’d say Reines for releasing his sauce killed dev

Then I would blame Andrew for throwing rsc away and ignoring the players[/quote]

Matt your a piece of shit dont fucking blame Reines, your server was the best until you got greedy and took peoples money.Way to be a dick. never trust a canadian.

item.title: Some things I want to ask
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

[quote=“Ecko, post:49, topic:398710”][quote author=IlikeArrays link=topic=495848.msg3634399#msg3634399 date=1308501070]

I’d say Reines for releasing his sauce killed dev

The source code was leaked without Reines’ permission.

Yes but he still initially released it.
[/quote]
He gave it to PR4Y. He did not release it, PR4Y did.[/quote]
The biggest mistake ever done in RSC scene. If he wouldn’t have done that, people would’ve realised that demonik is shit and somebody would have coded a better base, he would have hosted it for a while, but ended up trusting somebody he shouldn’t and the guy who he trusted would’ve gave it to us, ta-da we would be much further than we are now. Seriously, somebody should make a better base, and maybe I would be more interested to work on something RSC related.

Before you say “Make one yourself”, I simply don’t understand networking yet. I would make worse base than RSCD is.

Read full topic

I’m sure you’re blaming Kryptix for no reason.

item.dc:creator: @NoLives NoLives
item.description:
@NoLives wrote:

[quote=“Kryptix, post:16, topic:398743”][quote author=NoLives link=topic=495848.msg3633100#msg3633100 date=1308388109]
Okay, my point is, everyone knows that ur server is crap compared to other servers that were up at the time you started.
[/quote]
Maybe in your opinion but that means very little. If it’s ‘crap compared to other servers that were up’ then it wouldn’t have grown. We started with a blank database and went from there.[/quote]And as I stated earlier, you had people ddos other servers.
I don’t need to prove anything to you, because that is what I believe to be true.

Read full topic

@iPhone4 wrote:

Is this just a small number of users using rented botnets then? Why have they continued daily for several years? Who would care for that long? Whats the point?

I have always thought they DDoSed because they wanted to take down the competition and thus an “invite only, closed to the public” server would be safe. Is that not the case?

item.title: Some things I want to ask
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote author=NoLives link=topic=495848.msg3632352#msg3632352 date=1308337929]And not the fact that he had people ddos other servers?

Prove it… and even if that was true, I bet my right arm that the attacks were no where near as big and constant as the attacks we receive so it’s not really a viable excuse since I have to deal with it every single day…

It’s very rare that a day goes by without seeing at least a 1gB/s attack. There was a constant 5-18gB/s attack for several days according to Staminus. This costs thousands per month to protect against and is only possible through players subscribing. It’s a community effort to stay online. For anyone that doesn’t understand the chart, KO9 told me that the largest attack they ever saw was 6gB/s back when Tewl and Hixk was attacking them constantly. Now when I see it’s only 6gB/s I get relieved…

RSCEmulation started by GaWdZ hosting Project P2P’s source on his own personal PC with zero funding. It took us 2 months before we could afford a dedicated server through players donating. We worked our way up from there. You cannot even begin to try and blame me for other servers failing. It’s the servers owners responsibility to make it a success, it’s all to easy to blame your failure on someone else. I could have given up at one of the thousand hurdles I’ve had to go over and blame someone else but that’s not what makes a successful server that thousands of players play week in, week out.[/quote]

That’s because most skids just buy access to a ‘booter’ now, rather than actually making themselves a botnet (which they’d suck at). I’d think that a ‘booter’ would need to push at least 1 gbps if it was going to be useful, seeing people are now using VPNs with 1 gbps of DDoS protection. If a ‘booter’ is being used, just see if there is an interval that the attacks are happening (it should be around 2 minutes or so) where it lets up, then comes back.

Anyway, Staminus must be loving the attacks, seeing they’re low packet count, with pretty large packets (about 10 Kb / 1.25 KB for the massive peaks, and like 5-6 Kb / 0.6 - 0.75 KB for the rest of the decent sized attacks) and a low number of them. I would imagine that they stand out from the rest of the traffic. Though, it’s kind of hard to tell from the graph, especially because it seems like multiple attacks are going on in the same graph (for example, May 2, 11:32 2011 looks like it’s a different attack, because the packets are about 2 times bigger than attacks that have a massive peek).

Also, the attacks from April 6th to around April 8th seem to be slightly different than the attacks from April 8th, to April 10th. It’s really hard to tell though, seeing the graph’s scale is so large, and just the lack of data.

There is an interesting point on the graph (Jan 29, 00:17 2011) where the pps is much higher than the actual amount of data being sent (in kbps), I’m kind of curious as to what was going on.

It’s kind of funny that they’re wasting that much bandwidth to attack, when they could use a small fraction to attack at the application-layer and actually take it down. If they were to use those resources to just have accounts log in and walk around (while constantly wearing/removing items), I don’t see the software being able to handle that (especially how RSCD is). They could also simulate browsing the forums at a relatively high rate (for an actual person) and potentially make the web server have a rough time trying to handle all the requests.

Anyway, I should probably stop explaining how to take down servers, and get back to how to prevent/recognize an attack, as well as how they’re being executed.

Read full topic

item.source: Some things I want to ask

item.title: Some things I want to ask
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Jesse_, post:28, topic:398710”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=495848.msg3630630#msg3630630 date=1308179633]

You can’t protect from the attacks we receive… Regardless what software you have, it has to be filtered by the network as it eats up the entire bandwidth but before that happens the host simply nullroutes you. No one is gunna let 15gB/s eat up their bandwidth.

No one other than you has said there was an attack that big, so either someone has it out for you or the attacks really aren’t that big. Either way, if I decided to get a server it’ll have adequate protection against med-high range attacks. DDoS is not something I’m worried about.

Do you even have a clue what a mid-high range attack is?

Some DDoS attacks are hundreds of Gigabits per second… There is no way you can possibly claim you’ll be able to handle a large DDoS attack with 4 gbps protection, and a 1 gbps line.

You’d be lucky to handle a mid range attack, seeing you can cover the very low end of a mid-range attack. Furthermore, a 500 mbps attack could easily take your sever down, if it was done intelligently.
[/quote]

I understand you’re to defend your friend but I would love to see proof of an attack in the RSC scene that has reached anywhere near what you claim.[/quote]

I’m not defending anyone, I’m pointing out how ridiculous your claims are.

Also, I never claimed there have been attacks of several hundred gbps in the RSC scene, please learn how to read…

Anyway, finding someone with that can create a 10+ gbps isn’t that hard… All you need to do is go to pretty much any hacking forum…

Furthermore, a single computer can take down your game/site with an application-layer attack. Apache’s web server is easy to take down when the sysadmin doesn’t know how to configure it to handle attacks (which is pretty much everyone). RSCD is easy to take down as well… Anyone with a decent connection can take both down…

Read full topic

Lol[/quote]
if he is witch means i hope he is . still miss his pk servers they wore one of the best i ever played. rscpk come back to me i miss you
